Herein, the Zn-based catalysts with oxygen vacancies were obtained via the simple and effective method, and the oxygen-vacancy (Ov)-rich anatase TiO2 was as carrier, which was introduced oxygen-vacancy through heat treatment. The catalysts performance test results showed that the Zn/TiO2-300-10 with oxygen-vacancy (Ov)-rich exhibited excellent catalytic performance (acetylene conversion >89 % for 30 h) at the reaction temperature of 260 °C. Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy revealed the formation of oxygen-vacancy in treated TiO2 carriers. Subsequently, all the Zn-based catalysts were characterized by a series of characterization techniques. The results showed that the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst with Ov-rich could produce more hydroxyl‑containing Zn species and improve Zn dispersion than that of the untreated Zn/c-TiO2 catalysts. Meanwhile, the DFT calculation results showed that, for the oxygen-vacancy-rich Zn-based catalysts, the OH− species from (ZnOH)+ species participated in acetylene hydration, thereby reducing the activation energy of acetylene hydration, and allowing the regeneration of (ZnOH)+ species via water cleavage. While, the reactant C2H2 was directly reacted with water dissociation with higher activation energy for the Zn/TiO2 catalyst without oxygen-vacancy. This study lays the foundation for further developing other Ov-rich carriers more suitable for Zn loading. Graphical abstract TiO2-Ov carriers with oxygen vacancies (Ov) were obtained by heat treating TiO2 at low-medium temperatures. Zn/TiO2-Ov catalysts with Ov-rich obtained by loading Zn onto TiO2-Ov carriers effectively improve the dispersion of active metals and the formation of hydroxyl-containing zinc species, which are structurally beneficial to the attack of water molecules in the reactants, and the OH− species in the (ZnOH)+ species participate in the hydration of acetylene, which reduces the activation energy of the hydration of acetylene, and the regeneration of the (ZnOH)+ species via water cleavage for catalytic cycle. In contrast, the Zn/TiO2 catalysts obtained by loading Zn with TiO2 without Ov reacted directly with the reactant C2H2 via hydrolytic dissociation. This study lays the foundation for further developing other Ov-rich carriers more suitable for Zn loading. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene hydration Zn-base catalyst Oxygen vacancies Hydroxylzinc species DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Acetaldehyde, an intermediate of extremely important industrial chemicals, has numerous applications in pharmaceuticals, pesticide, and feed additives industries [1–3]. Currently, it is primarily synthesized via acetylene hydration and ethylene oxidation [4]. The ethylene oxidation process, which utilizes ethylene as a raw material, has been adversely affected by the overexploitation of petroleum and the escalating petroleum prices, resulting in a substantial rise in production costs [5,6]. The production of acetaldehyde via acetylene hydration has greater advantages than its production via ethylene oxidation because China is comparatively other countries rich in coal resources and the continuous improvement of coal acetylene technology [7–9]. The traditional hydration of acetylene to acetaldehyde mostly relies on mercury (Hg)-based catalysts [10,11]. Unfortunately, due to its high toxicity and volatility, this is inconsistent with the Chinese goal of green catalysis [12,13]. Therefore, it is imperative to develop mercury-free catalyst catalysts for acetylene hydration. Previous studies [14,15] have reported that the active components of acetylene hydration catalysts were primarily transition metal ions with full d-orbitals (e.g., Zn2+, Cu2+, Ag+, Au3+, Hg2+, and Cd2+). Considering economic benefits and environmental protection, many studies have focused on Zn-based catalysts and a few studies have focused on Cu-based catalysts. Most catalyst-improvement studies have focused on modifying catalyst carriers and active components. In Cu-based catalysts, activated carbon (AC) is primarily used as a carrier, and substances containing heteroatoms (e.g., N, P, and S) [16–20] are added to inhibit the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu monomers or improve the dispersion of Cu catalysts. However, the disadvantage of carbon carriers showed the poor hydrothermal stability, and it is unclear whether the active sites in Cu-based catalysts [21]. Besides, some reports have been made in the study of carrier modification, active component modification, and catalytic mechanism of Zn-based catalysts for the acetylene hydration. To overcome the poor hydrothermal stability of AC-based carriers, pure silica molecular sieves have been used as carriers in Zn-based catalysts because of their good hydrothermal stability. Zn-Cu/MCM-41 [22], Zn-La/MCM-41 [23], and Zn-Bi/MCM-41 [24] catalysts exhibit good catalytic performance in the acetylene hydration reaction. Owing to the addition of the second metal, these catalysts suppress carbon buildup and improve the dispersion of Zn species. However, the introduction of the second metal could not solve the shortcoming of the MCM-41 carrier, such as the few active sites. Therefore, it is a good way to introduce some vacancy defects or groups into the MCM-41 carrier to increase the number of active sites of on the carrier. Wang et al. [25,4,26–28] performed a series of modifications on MCM-41 carriers, including group modification (NH2 −) [25,4], oxygen plasma treatment of metals [26] and doping (e.g. Zr [27] and, Ti [28]). Their results showed that carrier modification has great advantages, which could produce more active sites and some defects on MCM-41, and the presence of carrier defect sites would be favorable for the reaction. Li et al. [29] showed that the presence of carrier defects promotes electron rearrangement, which favors the adsorption of reactants on the catalysts by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Chen et al. [30,31] also showed that Zn-based catalyst containing OH− species could promote the acetylene hydration reaction. It is well known that the carrier plays an important role in the catalyst. According to the relevant literatures, the carriers with oxygen vacancies could have a synergistic effect on the adsorption and dissociation of water into OH−. However, the main component of MCM-41 support is SiO2 species, which is a non-reducible oxide and produces fewer and more difficult defects. Through the literatures research, it is found that oxygen vacancies are one of the most important defects that act as reactive sites in a variety of catalytic reactions. For example, oxygen vacancies in the carriers synergize with the deposited metal to optimize the reaction kinetics [32]. Additionally, the presence of surface oxygen vacancies could enhance the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules; reduce the activation energy and accelerate the surface catalyzed reaction [33–35]. Based on this, it is relatively easy to introduce defect sites intoTiO2, a reducible oxide, especially anatase TiO2 carriers. Loading metals such as Pd [32] or Cu [36] on Ov-rich TiO2 carriers significantly enhance the electronic interactions between metals and carriers. Anatase TiO2 is also characterized with good hydrothermal stability and environmental friendliness. Therefore, herein, anatase TiO2 carriers with oxygen vacancies were designed and synthesized, and obtain the Zn/TiO2-Ov catalysts for the acetylene hydration reaction to systematically investigate the effect of Ov on the catalytic performance of Zn/TiO2-Ov catalysts. All the catalysts were analyzed by serials of characterization techniques, and the reaction mechanism was studied by DFT calculation. This study aims to inspire further development of other Ov-rich carriers that are more suitable for Zn-based catalysts in the hydration of acetylene. 2 Experimental and characterization equipment 2.1 Raw materials Isopropyl titanate (C12H28O4Ti, 95 %), zinc chloride (ZnCl2, 98 %), activated carbon (40–60 mesh), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 30–40 wt%) were used as purchased without further treatment. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 TiO2-x-y preparation Anatase TiO2 carriers were synthesized via a method similar to the sol-gel method mentioned reported in a previous study [37]. First, 200 mL of isopropanol was taken in a beaker. Second, 18 mL of isopropyl titanate and 0.43 g of AC were slowly added to the beaker with stirring. Third, solution A (1.5 mL of hydrochloric acid and 20 mL of water) was added dropwise to the beaker until a gel formed. Once the gel formed, stirring was stopped, and the gel aged for 12 h and, dried for 10 h in an oven at 70 °C. The dried gel was calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min to remove the activated carbon template. The sample obtained was named as plain TiO2 (c-TiO2). Subsequently, c-TiO2 was calcined again in a muffle furnace at different temperatures and different times. The corresponding samples were named TiO2-x-y, where x is the calcination temperature in °C (x = 100, 200, 300, 400) and y is the calcination time in h (y = 5, 10, 15). 2.2.2 Zn/TiO2-x-y catalyst preparation Zn-based catalysts were prepared via a simple impregnation method. The procedure for synthesizing Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts was as follows: firstly, 20 mL of deionized water was added to a beaker, followed by the addition of ZnCl2, and after waiting for the full dissolution of ZnCl2, the prepared carriers were slowly added and stirred for 24 h at room temperature, and then dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The resulting catalyst was named Zn/TiO2-x-y. The Zn loading was fixed at 7.2 wt%. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation All catalyst performance tests were performed in a homemade fixed-bed microreactor (φ10 mm × 500 mm). 2 mL of the catalyst samples were placed in the middle of the microreactor tube. The reaction temperature was 240 °C, and the reaction tube was purged with N2 for 30 min to remove water vapor and air. Then, the N2 flow was turned off, the C2H2 flow was turned on, and acetylene and water vapor were injected into the reactor according to GHSV(C2H2) = 90 h−1 and n(H2O)/n(C2H2) = 4. Finally, the products were analyzed using GC-2014C. The products were quantified using the peak area normalization method. The conversion was calculated as the number of acetylene reacted divided by the number of acetylenes in the feed gas. In this experiment, acetylene conversion (XA) and acetaldehyde selectivity (SVC) were used as the evaluation indices of catalyst performance. The formulas were calculated as follows: X A = ∅ A 0 − ∅ A ∅ A × 100 % S V C = ∅ V C 1 − ∅ A × 100 % Where ∅ A 0 is the volume fraction of acetylene in the reactants before the reaction; ∅ A is the volume fraction of acetylene left unreacted in the product after the reaction; and ∅ VC is the volume fraction of acetaldehyde in the product after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of TiO2-x-y carriers The crystal structures of the carriers were investigated via powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The XRD patterns of a TiO2-x-y carriers exhibit the characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2, such as (1 0 1), (0 0 4), and (2 0 0). This indicates that anatase TiO2 was successfully synthesized. Furthermore, the enlarged XRD patterns show that the positions of the (1 0 1) and (2 0 0) peaks of TiO2-x-y shift compared to those in the XRD pattern of c-TiO2. This shift can be attributed to defect formation [38]. To further characterize the oxygen vacancies on the TiO2-x-y carriers, a series of characterizations were performed to ensure oxygen vacancies could be introduced into the TiO2-x-y carriers by treating them at medium-low temperatures. The optical properties of all TiO2-x-y carriers were characterized via ultraviolet (UV) visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), as shown in Fig. 1(b). TiO2-300-10 exhibits higher light absorption than c-TiO2, probably because it has a higher concentration of Ti3+ centers and oxygen vacancies. Subsequently, the TiO2-x-y carriers were characterized via Raman spectroscopy under visible excitation (532 nm), as shown in Fig. 1(c). The Raman spectrum of TiO2-x-y exhibits peaks similar to those in the Raman spectrum of anatase TiO2, including Eg, B1g, A1g, and E1g peaks, consistent with XRD results. Fig. 1(c) shows an obvious shift in the Eg peak after medium-low temperature treatment, probably because of defect formation. To confirm the presence of oxygen vacancies in the TiO2-x-y carriers and further investigate their properties, the TiO2-x-y carriers were characterized via in situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy, and the results are shown in Fig. 1(d). TiO2-200-10, TiO2-300-10, and TiO2-400-10 carriers exhibit more pronounced EPR signal intensity at g = 2.003 than c-TiO2, and the signal intensity magnitude is TiO2-300-10 > TiO2-400-10 > TiO2-200-10. According to the literature, the signal at g = 2.003 ± 0.001 can be attributed to the oxygen vacancies on the TiO2 surface, indicating the presence of surface oxygen vacancies on TiO2-300-10. This result is consistent with Raman and DRS results. To further verify the chemical structure of the obtained TiO2-x-y carriers, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed. Fig. 2 (a) shows the high-resolution Ti 2p XPS spectrum of carriers, in which the two peaks at 458.6 eV and 464.4 eV correspond to Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2, respectively [39]. The Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 in the XPS spectrum of TiO2-x-y shift toward smaller binding energies after heat treatment, indicating the presence of Ti3+ species in TiO2-x-y [40]. Furthermore, the large shift of the Ti 2p peak in the XPS spectrum of the TiO2-300-10 carrier indicates the formation of more Ti3+. Fig. 2(b) shows the high-resolution O 1s XPS spectra of carriers, in which the peaks at 529.8 eV and 531.5 eV correspond to lattice oxygen (Ti4+-O) and bridging hydroxyl groups tightly bound to oxygen vacancies, respectively. According to the peak area ratios, the concentrations of oxygen vacancies in c-TiO2, TiO2-100-10, TiO2-200-10, TiO2-300-10, and TiO2-400-10 carriers are 13 %, 14 %, 15 %, 18 %, and 16 %, respectively, consistent with the above results. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts As discussed in Section 3.1, some oxygen vacancies were introduced in TiO2-x-y carriers after medium-low temperature calcination treatment. Therefore, the catalytic performance of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts in the acetylene hydration reaction was studied to investigate the effect of oxygen vacancies on the performance of Zn-based catalysts in this reaction. The analysis of the catalytic performance of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts at a reaction temperature of 240 °C (Fig. 3 ), shows that the acetaldehyde selectivity and acetylene conversion increased as the oxygen vacancies concentration in the carrier increases, especially the former. Among all synthesized Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts, the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst exhibits the best catalytic performance in the acetylene hydration reaction for 10 h, and the conversion of acetylene to acetaldehyde on the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst is > 96.88 %. This indicates that the higher the oxygen vacancies content of the carrier, the better the catalytic performance of the Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts. To further study the catalytic performance of the optimal Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst, its reaction temperature was optimized (Fig. S3). Because the optimal temperature for introducing oxygen vacancies in TiO2-x-y is 300 °C, the calcination time was optimized, and the catalytic performance of Zn/TiO2-300-y catalysts was studied at this temperature (Fig S4). The results of performance tests conducted at a reaction temperature of 260 °C for 30 h are shown in Fig. 4 . The acetylene conversion on Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst was higher than 89 % compared to Zn/c-TiO2 catalyst. However, the acetylene conversion on Zn/c-TiO2 catalyst decreased rapidly from 91.1 % (highest) to 36.2 % (lowest) under the same reaction conditions. These results confirm that the introduction of oxygen vacancies in carrier could effectively improve the catalytic performance of Zn-based catalysts in the acetylene hydration reaction. 3.2.1 Performance enhancement analysis To understand how the introduction of oxygen vacancies affects the performance of Zn-based catalysts, fresh Zn/c-TiO2 catalyst and Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst were characterized via high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and these results are shown in Fig. 5 . Comparison of the HRTEM images of Zn/c-TiO2 (Fig. 5(a)) and Zn/TiO2-300-10 (Fig. 5(b)) catalysts shows that the lattice fringes in the HRTEM image of the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst correspond to Zn species with more hydroxyl groups, such as ZnOHCl (PDF#32-1467) and Zn5(OH)8Cl2·H2O (PDF#07-0155). The presence of oxygen vacancies in TiO2-300-10 catalyst may allow the transformation of ZnCl2 into more reactive Zn species containing hydroxyl groups. Meanwhile, the fresh catalysts were further characterized via energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) to understand the distribution of Zn and other elements on the catalyst surface. EDS images (Fig. 5(g–j)) of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts show that the dispersion of Zn species in the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst is more homogeneous than that in the Zn/c-TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 5(c–f)). This implies that the presence of oxygen vacancies in the carriers promotes the dispersion of Zn species on the catalyst surface. This is consistent with the literature, which reported that oxygen vacancies could promote the dispersion of active species [41,42]. To investigate the potential impact of oxygen vacancies on the loaded Zn species, the crystal structures of the Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts were analyzed via XRD before and after the reaction, as shown in Fig. 6 . The intensity of the peaks of ZnCl2·1.33H2O in the XRD pattern of the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst is significantly lower than that in the XRD pattern of the Zn/c-TiO2 catalyst. This difference may be attributed to the improved dispersion of ZnCl2 on the TiO2-300-10 carrier or its conversion to other Zn species containing hydroxyl groups (e.g., ZnOHCl and Zn5(OH)8Cl2·H2O). This finding is consistent with HRTEM results. The surface electronic structure of the Zn/TiO2-x-y catalyst before and after the reaction was studied via XPS. Fig. 7 shows that the presence of oxygen vacancies shifts the Zn 2p3/2 peak towards lower binding energies. This indicates that Zn gains electrons, increasing the electron cloud density around the Zn species. The Zn 2p3/2 XPS spectrum of Zn/TiO2-x-y can be deconvoluted into two peaks corresponding to the two chemical states of Zn, where the peak with a high binding energy corresponds (ZnOH)+, and the peak with a low binding energy corresponds to (ZnH)+. Table 1 shows the contents of (ZnH)+ and (ZnOH)+ in all Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts. From the Table 1 results, as the oxygen vacancies content in Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts, increases more (ZnOH)+ species are produced in the catalysts. The (ZnOH)+ content of the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst is 48.5 %, whereas the (ZnOH)+ content of the Zn/c-TiO2 catalyst is only 31.6 %. This may be attributed to the presence of oxygen vacancies in fresh Zn/TiO2-300-10, which facilitate the cleavage of water molecules during the reaction. This cleavage generates hydroxyl radicals and forms (ZnOH)+ species with Zn. It has been shown that increasing the number of (ZnOH)+ species in catalyst improves the catalytic performance of Zn-based catalysts in the reaction. Furthermore, the content of (ZnOH)+ species in the used catalysts were decreased, which may be due to the dehydroxylation reaction of (ZnOH)+ to form more (ZnH)+ under the reducing gas acetylene atmosphere, which leads to the decrease of catalytic activity. The adsorption of acetylene (reactant) by the catalyst affects the catalytic performance of the catalyst, and fresh catalysts were characterized via C2H2-temperature-programmed desorption (C2H2-TPD). Fig. 8 shows the acetylene desorption profiles of fresh Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts at 50–600 °C. The peaks in the temperature range of 300–500 °C in the C2H2-TPD profile of Zn-based catalysts are the desorption peaks of acetylene. The C2H2-TPD profile of the Zn/c-TiO2 catalyst exhibits two desorption peaks in the temperature range of 300–500 °C; therefore, the desorption temperature of Zn/c-TiO2 is between 399.18 °C and 464.85 °C, and the desorption peak of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalyst appears at 397.92 °C. This implies that the presence of carrier oxygen vacancies in Zn-based catalysts reduces the acetylene adsorption temperature, which may also improve the catalytic performance of Zn-based catalysts. Among Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts the acetylene desorption peak area is in the order of Zn/c-TiO2 > Zn/TiO2-400-10 > Zn/TiO2-200-10 > Zn/TiO2-300-10 > Zn/TiO2-100-10. However, Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst exhibits the best catalytic performance, implying that moderate acetylene adsorption facilitates the acetylene hydration reaction, whereas excessive acetylene adsorption leads to carbon buildup. Carbon deposition is an important factor affecting the performance of the catalyst in the C2H2 reaction atmosphere. To investigate the effect of the presence of oxygen vacancies in the carrier on carbon buildup on Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts, thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 and Fig. S5. The results indicate that all Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts exhibit significant weight loss in the temperature intervals of 40–130 °C (Ⅰ), 130–400 °C (Ⅱ) and 400–900 °C (Ⅲ). The weight loss in interval I is due to bound water in the catalyst, and the weight loss of the fresh catalyst is higher in this interval, which may be related to the susceptibility of ZnCl2 to deliquescence. The weight loss in interval II may be due to the melting of ZnCl2 [43,44]. Therefore, the difference between the pre- and post-reaction weight loss of the catalyst in interval III can be regarded as carbon deposition. For example, the carbon deposition of Zn/c-TiO2 is 7.62 % and 5.78 %, and the difference between the two is 1.84 %. These results in table 2 show that the TiO2 carrier can better resist carbon buildup than other carriers, and the presence of oxygen vacancies in the carrier further improve the pit carbon accumulation of Zn-based catalysts. 3.3 Reaction mechanism analysis As the above results, XPS, Raman, and EPR results indicate the presence of oxygen vacancies in the TiO2-300-10 carrier. Therefore, aerobic vacancy (TiO2-Ov) and anaerobic vacancy (TiO2)-loaded Zn models were constructed on the (1 0 1) crystalline surfaces of TiO2 to determine its catalytic mechanism for the acetylene hydration reaction. The reaction energy paths and geometrical configurations of the corresponding states are shown in Fig. 10 . The adsorption energy of the catalyst for the reactants (i.e., acetylene and water) was calculated, as shown in Table S2. On the one hand, the adsorption energy of water is greater than that of acetylene; therefore, for the initial state (Re) of co-adsorption (Co-ads), with or without vacancies water is preferentially adsorbed before the formation of the Co-ads state. On the other hand, the geometrical configuration shows that the hydroxyl group of the catalyst without defects attached to Zn is in a plane with Zn, which is not favorable for the reaction to occur, and the larger bond angle of Cl further prevents the reaction from occurring, so that C2H2 directly adducts with H+ and OH− (formed by cleavage of water) to form the final state (Fs), which subsequently desorbs to form a vinyl alcohol structure (De), and due to the unstable isomerization of the vinyl alcohol structure to obtain the final product, acetaldehyde (Pr), with a reaction activation energy of 1.23 eV. The Ov-rich catalyst not only enhanced the adsorption of water but also facilitated the reaction in the spatial structure because the hydroxyl group of Zn-OH was involved in the reaction and could be regenerated by the dissociation of H2O to obtain Zn-OH, which realized the catalytic cycling of the reaction system, thus lowering the activation energy of the reaction with an activation energy of only 0.84 eV. Theoretical calculations demonstrated that the presence of carrier oxygen vacancies enabled the Zn-based catalysts to enhance the adsorption of reactants, reduce the activation energy of the reaction and improve the catalytic performance of the Zn-based catalysts through the participation of Zn-linked –OH in the reaction as well as the catalytic cycling of the reaction system through the dissociation and regeneration of water. 4 Conclusion Oxygen-vacancy were introduced in synthesized anatase TiO2 using simple medium-low temperature heat treatment. A series of Zn/TiO2-x-y catalysts were prepared for acetylene hydration reactions. At an optimal reaction temperature of 260 °C, the acetylene conversion on Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst remained > 89 % for 30 h, indicating that the presence of Ov in TiO2-300-10 catalyst enhanced the catalytic activity of Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance of Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst was attributed to the presence of oxygen vacancies, which converted the active substance ZnCl2 into a hydroxy zinc active species, favoring the reaction and increasing the dispersion of Zn in TiO2-300-10 catalyst. Theoretical calculations showed that the structure with oxygen vacancies is more favorable for the reaction when loaded with Zn species OH− in (ZnOH)+ species participates in the reaction, which reduces the activation energy of the reaction illustrated. This study preliminarily explored the relationship between oxygen vacancies and catalytic performance of Zn-based catalysts and provided research ideas for developing other Ov-rich carriers for Zn-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Herein, the Zn-based catalysts with oxygen vacancies were obtained via the simple and effective method, and the oxygen-vacancy (Ov)-rich anatase TiO2 was as carrier, which was introduced oxygen-vacancy through heat treatment. The catalysts performance test results showed that the Zn/TiO2-300-10 with oxygen-vacancy (Ov)-rich exhibited excellent catalytic performance (acetylene conversion >89 % for 30 h) at the reaction temperature of 260 °C. Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy revealed the formation of oxygen-vacancy in treated TiO2 carriers. Subsequently, all the Zn-based catalysts were characterized by a series of characterization techniques. The results showed that the Zn/TiO2-300-10 catalyst with Ov-rich could produce more hydroxyl‑containing Zn species and improve Zn dispersion than that of the untreated Zn/c-TiO2 catalysts. Meanwhile, the DFT calculation results showed that, for the oxygen-vacancy-rich Zn-based catalysts, the OH− species from (ZnOH)+ species participated in acetylene hydration, thereby reducing the activation energy of acetylene hydration, and allowing the regeneration of (ZnOH)+ species via water cleavage. While, the reactant C2H2 was directly reacted with water dissociation with higher activation energy for the Zn/TiO2 catalyst without oxygen-vacancy. This study lays the foundation for further developing other Ov-rich carriers more suitable for Zn loading.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen vacancies prompt the formation of hydrated hydroxyzinc in Zn-based catalysts to enhance acetylene hydration
